result.execSummary:
The defendant Michael A Keppert was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of THC, an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(e).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Bond applied and any balance shall be returned to whomever posted.   

Defendant shall, within three (3) days, contact the Washington County Jail for purposes of supplying a biological specimen for DNA analysis.  Defendant has the right to request expungement of DNA analysis in writing through the Department of Justice.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Michael A Keppert

records.addlTxt: to Poster

Def in person & by Atty Jeremy J Guza.  Atty Mandy A. Schepper appeared for State. On a plea to C. 1, State moves to dismiss Ct. 2 for read in;   Guilty plea entered on Ct. 1;   Court finds def guilty on Ct. 1, on motion of the State, Court dismisses Ct. 2 for read in; Joint recommendation for fine; Argument from State, Defense; Court proceeds to sentencing, imposes fine of $673.50, bond shall be applied, any balance shall be returned to the poster;  Defendant shall, within three (3) days, contact the Washington County Jail for purposes of supplying a biological specimen for DNA analysis.  Court informs Defendant of DNA expungement rights.
